Award.AwardTitle: CRII: Cyberlearning: Mobile Computers to Enhance the Building Industry and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The building industry has been criticized for lagging in productivity compared to other industries and for wasting billions of dollars annually due to interoperability. Part of this industry's challenge is that buildings cannot be physically prototyped to test performance, making every new building a first-of-its-kind. To help plan for unique designs, project teams often create either physical or virtual reality (VR) mockups of critical spaces (hospital patient rooms, courtrooms, etc.) to inform project decisions. While physical mockups do enable intuitive exploration, they can be challenging for quickly testing "what-if" design alternatives. And while VR mockups allow for quick consideration of design alternatives, they can only simulate navigation through a physical space, which can skew the comprehension of a design by VR users. This CRII research aims to use augmented reality (AR) to realize, at once, both the physical exploration benefits of purely physical mockups and the rapid-design-concept-experimentation benefits of VR mockups. Similar to the yellow "first-down" line on televised American football games, AR allows users to see virtual content superimposed on top of a real view of a space. Mobile information technologies (IT), including smartphones, tablets, and head-mounted displays (HMD), will be used with existing Building Information Model (BIM) content to enable AR-based design and constructability review sessions. Industry participants will use the resulting technologies to view and modify room layouts based on their project concerns. The perceptions and observable behaviors of the research participants will be recorded and analyzed. This will contribute to a better understanding of how AR may facilitate (or potentially hinder) design comprehension among industry practitioners when generating project decisions. Ultimately, this project will provide a critical resource for future researchers and practitioners who need to strategically plan for the use of technology that affords specific human benefits.

The PI on this work has partnered with design and construction companies in Phoenix, AZ. These companies will share BIM content for upcoming projects, which will be imported into the Unity game engine and linked to printed fiducial markers using Vuforia in order to enable AR registration. This development approach will allow the same AR environment to be exported to each of the Android-based mobile IT devices explored. Once all AR devices are prepared for the review sessions, industry participants will experiment with the placement of printed fiducial markers. Each marker will represent a single building element to allow for design modifications. When participants view the markers with the provided mobile IT, they will see a corresponding AR mockup at full scale. This case-study approach will allow the PI to explore the process of design review in a natural and realistic context while testing the AR visualization as a research intervention. Pre- and post-activity questionnaires will be used to collect perception-based feedback from the participants, while video and audio recordings will provide documentation for subsequent analysis of observed behaviors. The investigator hypothesizes that, even though all devices will technically show the same AR environment, the AR will nevertheless enable (or hinder) design comprehension differently for different participants. Because such differences may impact decision-making, the design comprehension impacts will be specifically measured using existing construction-related frameworks (Conceptual Product/Process Matrix model, or CPPMM; and the DEEPAND framework: Description, Explanation, Evaluation, Prediction, Alternatives, Negotiation, Decisionmaking) for assessing design and constructability review sessions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to understand how mobile information technologies (IT) and augmented (or "mixed") reality (AR/MR) can influence design comprehension for industry practitioners and students in the Architecture, Engineering, Construction, and Operation (AECO) fields. More specifically, the work strategically explored common contexts within this domain that do not typically incorporate AR into current workflows in order to understand its impact on design communication. These contexts include:

  • Design contexts: The research team developed, implemented, and evaluated an AR design review prototype aimed at enabling practitioners and students to quickly comprehend design concepts, while also being able to intuitively navigate these concepts through physical exploration of a space.
  • Construction contexts: The team identified pre-, during, and post-construction use-cases where AR is not typically used in order to determine the ways in which its use may enable design comprehension for faster construction with fewer errors.
  • Operational contexts: The team developed an AR prototype to enable individuals to explore a virtual space in order to identify design attributes that may not effectively support building operators and generate suggestions for how the space might be modified to better support operation and maintenance tasks.

 

Where possible, the researchers randomly assigned participants to use either AR or more traditional modes of design communication. This provided benchmark performance levels to which AR performance could be compared. This methodology led to several major findings that provide intellectual merit related to how AR enables design comprehension in the AECO domain, which are outlined below.

  • AR can enable the physical exploration benefits of physical mockups with the rapid modification benefits of virtual mockups in order to support effective design review decision-making.
  • AR enables significantly faster layout during pre-construction tasks than current paper-based methods, but with marginally lower accuracy.
  • AR supports faster completion of basic construction tasks than paper and can reduce the number of errors made during these tasks.
  • AR can enable rapid and consistent identification of deviations made during building construction to enable design and construction models to be updated to accurately reflect as-built conditions.
  • AR can enable un- and under-trained individuals to complete various different construction tasks as well, or nearly as well, as current practitioners, which provides a potentially valuable communication approach to address workforce shortage issues in the industry.
  • AR can enable more consistent classification of flawed building design elements that could pose challenges for building operators in order to redesign these elements before they become problematic during building operation.

 

This work offers broader impact to the AECO fields and beyond. At present, the building industry is unique from many others because the "product" produced by this industry is rarely the same from project to project. Similarly, the team of individuals who work to deliver a project is rarely the same from project to project. This underscores the importance of having team members effectively comprehend building designs on every project to enable them to understand the design concepts generated by other stakeholders in order to make wise design and construction decisions based on those concepts. At present, this process of comprehending designs is typically done using 2D documents or non-immersive design models viewed on a computer screen. Both formats of presentation typically show design concepts outside the context of the real, physical, construction site. The findings from this work, not only illustrate how AR may be able to provide value by presenting design models within the context of the field, but they also illustrate the types, and attributes, of use-cases where AR may be especially beneficial for supporting design comprehension necessary for completing certain tasks and making certain decisions. This knowledge may impact researchers and practitioners in this domain considering the use of AR for AECO-related design communication. While these findings offer broad impact to the AECO domain, the findings are envisioned to support AR decision-making for other fields where design comprehension is critical. Furthermore, this work also identifies the types of use-cases where un- and under-trained individuals are able to use AR in order to complete tasks as well, or nearly as well, as trained professionals, which may support decisions related to using AR for workforce development needs.
